p: Looking forward, the discipline of quantitative genetics is merging with the field of ‘big data’ analytics, a ground for ML ( Figure 1). An expanded view of complex traits is arising, moving from a polygenic framework to a view in which all genes are liable to affect adaptation to abiotic stresses [ 220], so that most heritability can be explained by the effects of rare variants [ 221, 222] and their interactions with epigenetic factors [ 223]. However, looking back toward the bases of crop evolution [ 23, 24] still has the potential to improve agriculture because natural selection has tested more options than humans ever will [ 35]. We envision that mining the molecular footprint of selection and adaptation in wild crop relatives and early landraces for plant breeding [ 224] and climate adaptation [ 125, 225] will benefit from bridging the gap between phenotyping ( Figure 1a) and genotyping ( Figure 1e) in genebanks [ 226, 227], and the more classical and deterministic conceptual models from the fields of quantitative and population genetics.
